newsitem.title: CANADA: Strong earnings boost some Toronto shares.
newsitem.headline: Strong earnings boost some Toronto shares.

text.p: Strong quarterly earnings propelled selected shares higher in some industry sectors on Thursday in active trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
"I think earnings has been a big push," said ScotiaMcLeod Senior Vice-President Fred Ketchen.
Companies have benefited from low interest rates, Ketchen said.
"A couple of companies that have had good numbers are doing okay," said Calgary-based portfolio manager Josef Schachter.
Canadian National Railway Co jumped 2.90 to 52.60 and was among Toronto's top gainers, after reporting a first- quarter profit of C$1.51 a share on Thursday, versus year earlier C$0.92.
Chief Executive Paul Tellier forecast a lower operating ratio for 1997, which measures operating expenses as a percentage of revenues. A lower operating ratio means a stronger railway performance.

Fertilizer firm Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc rose 0.90 to 105.50. Despite a fall in first-quarter earnings to US$1.18 a share from US$1.40 last year, the firm posted its second highest quarterly income ever of US$56.4 million, Potash said.
Steelmaker Samuel Manu-Tech Inc climbed 1.75 to 19.75 after first-quarter earnings rose to C$0.42 a share from C$0.34.
